lines.text: Planets move in elliptical orbits with the Sun at one focus

definitions.def: Planets move in elliptical orbits around the Sun, with the Sun at a focus of the ellipse.

secText: Starting in 1609, the astronomer Johannes Kepler proposed the three basic laws of planetary motion.

Kepler demonstrated that all planets have elliptical orbits. For example, we show that Mars’ orbit around the Sun has an elliptical shape. This is his first law, and it applies to satellites, including Earth, orbiting any massive central body, such as the Sun. It applies equally well to the Moon orbiting the Earth.

Kepler observed that the Sun is located at one focus of every planetary orbit. A focus is one of two points that defines an ellipse.  A circle is an ellipse in which the two focal points coincide, so Kepler’s law applies to circular orbits as well.
